components.name: eucanetd
components.description: Used to track component level items associated with Edge.

fields.description:
Opening this bug to track an issue brought up in automated QA sequences where the hypervisor's default network's dhcpd process is conflicting with eucanetd's ability to run dhcpd (assuming port conflict). There appears to be a recent change in dhcpd which will not allow the two server to bind to the same udp port. 

The first part of this ticket is to suggest that eucanetd propagate this error upstream. Suggesting that the process communicate errors such to the node (or other mechanism upstream) so the nc process can communicate the node's inability to service VM state upstream for an admin/operator to take action. This will also prevent new VMs from landing on this node. This is something that needs to be scoped and design. 

Doc suggestion for the immediate release...
Our documentation should also note that the default network for the hypervisor should be destroyed and/or dnsmasq process killed. Example below:

{code}
[root@a-15 ~]# ps aux | grep dhcp
root      1167  0.0  0.0   9120   988 ?        Ss   Oct19   0:05 /sbin/dhclient -q -cf /etc/dhcp/dhclient-em1.conf -lf /var/lib/dhclient/dhclient-em1.leases -pf /var/run/dhclient-em1.pid em1
nobody    1877  0.0  0.0  12892   580 ?        S    Oct19   0:05 /usr/sbin/dnsmasq --strict-order --pid-file=/var/run/libvirt/network/default.pid --conf-file= --except-interface lo --bind-interfaces --listen-address 192.168.122.1 --dhcp-range 192.168.122.2,192.168.122.254 --dhcp-leasefile=/var/lib/libvirt/dnsmasq/default.leases --dhcp-lease-max=253 --dhcp-no-override --dhcp-hostsfile=/var/lib/libvirt/dnsmasq/default.hostsfile --addn-hosts=/var/lib/libvirt/dnsmasq/default.addnhosts
root     19850  0.0  0.0 103256   836 pts/0    S+   15:10   0:00 grep dhcp

[root@a-15 ~]# virsh net-destroy default
Network default destroyed

[root@a-15 ~]# 
[root@a-15 ~]# 
[root@a-15 ~]# ps aux | grep dhcp
root      1167  0.0  0.0   9120   988 ?        Ss   Oct19   0:05 /sbin/dhclient -q -cf /etc/dhcp/dhclient-em1.conf -lf /var/lib/dhclient/dhclient-em1.leases -pf /var/run/dhclient-em1.pid em1
root     19894  0.0  0.0 103252   828 pts/0    S+   15:10   0:00 grep dhcp

[root@a-15 ~]# cat /etc/redhat-release 
CentOS release 6.5 (Final)
{code}
fields.summary: eucanetd can not start dhcpd due to udp port binding conflict from dnsmasq

comments.body: Added to known issues list for 4.1 release notes.
Possible inclusion of faults in this use case.
Suggestion for the fix: to log an error message and a fault if this condition is detected.

there is already an log message when dhcpd fails to run, but it doesn't do further analysis as to why.

one low impact improvement would be to include (when DHCPd fails to run) a small check to see if dnsmasq is running (or better, if the UDP dhcpd ports are already bound), and alert the user via log message that there dhcpd failed likely due to a conflicting dnsmasq process also running on the host.

medium impact improvement would be to both do the above, and also add to the NC pre-check code a check for dnsmasq/UDP port binding on NC startup as well

-d

Hi [~nurmi]

I've got a fix for this issue, which does the port check to see if there is another process listening when we try to launch the dhcpd server. It will log an error in eucanetd.log, and generate a fault in the newly created eucanetd-fault.log. There are two faults:
1) We know there is another process listening on port 67
2) We don't know why the process couldn't start (doesn't seem to be another process listening).
In both cases the fault will direct the user to perform the appropriate actions via the resolution section. 

The current behavior of eucanetd is to continue trying to start/restart the dhcpd server if there is an error returned. I'm thinking of changing this, so that the error is considered fatal and eucanetd will stop running. This should have a cascading effect, in that the Node Controller will now throw a fit because eucanetd is not running. I'd like to stay away from putting the check into the NC aside from "is eucanetd running". 

Can you think of any reasons to not make this a fatal error condition?

[~sgraham]

generally, I think fatal/exit conditions should only kick when we're extremely sure that the component can not continue to operate - historically, there have been times when a single dhcpd attempt would fail but subsequent would succeed (for a variety of reasons outside of our control), and so I would not classify a single dhcpd failure in this category.  

I do think that a running dnsmasq detection could potentially be classified this way, especially in the init script pre-check (i.e. eucanetd never runs in the first place if dnsmasq is running).  

Thats my 2cents!

-D

hi [~sgraham]

the code looks good to me - one observation:

this bit of code is adding quite a few new 'command' requirements for the init script to function (find, awk, cut) - I believe that these utils are all part of CentOS/RHEL6 minimal, but it might be good to double check.  Historically, we have had some troubles when we assume some command availability but it then is not present in some environment in the field.  One way to make it a bit safer is to write a few checks before the code that checks that the requisite commands are present (which also will prevent a situation where the code is run with missing commands which can cause strange output/behavior).  Also specifying full paths to the commands is good since init scripts can sometimes have different environments on boot via in a shell.  a real simple

if [ -x /bin/find -a -x /bin/awk -a -x /bin/cut ]; then
  echo YAY
else
  echo 'cannot find required commands: /bin/find /bin/awk /bin/cut'
  exit 1
fi

or something along those lines might prevent some future issues

since we're pretty tied to centOS/RHEL 6 right now I don't think this is strictly required (assuming that we double check that the required commands are part of CentOS/RHEL 6 minimal), but when we move to RHEL 7 these types of checks will make it clear from the get-go where we stand :)

-D

Hi [~nurmi],

I kept my script as is, I verified that find/awk/cut are in the minimal distro. Also I looked at other startup scripts (not ours) and they also use them. I also didn't specify the whole path as PATH is set in our script. This seems like the least amount of risk at the moment, although I do agree with your statements in regards to verifying they exist.

Also saw this discussion on stackoverflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/592620/check-if-a-program-exists-from-a-bash-script
That should be a more "portable" way, if we add multiple distros, by using {{ type }} (or one of the others) to verify the command is in the path. 

-Steve

Fix merged to maint-4.1 (4.1.2): 
eucalyptus commit 63cf178cfd2cbec5ac1469e6d0b6e711112d3517

Verified the init script output/error and nc.fault. 
Looks like the node transitioned to DISABLED state during the next run request (when eucanetd is not running on it). 
Thanks!
-M 

{code}
[root@g-26-04 eucalyptus]# 
[root@g-26-04 eucalyptus]# service eucanetd start
Starting Eucalyptus eucanetd: Cannot start eucanetd: /usr/sbin/dnsmasq (pid:24093), is listening on the DHCP service port (67).

[root@g-26-04 eucalyptus]# date
Thu Jul  9 12:01:52 PDT 2015

[root@g-26-04 eucalyptus]# cat nc-fault.log 
************************************************************************
  ERR-1008 2015-06-25 13:46:27Z eucanetd is not running

       Cause: unknown

    Location: eucanetd daemon on localhost
  Resolution: 
        1) Install eucanetd
        2) Run eucanetd

        2) Run eucanetd
      
************************************************************************
